{{Infobox ethnic group |group = Igbo people in Jamaica
Eboe |image = |caption = |population = N/A |popplace = Primarily Northwestern Jamaica, especially the ports of [[Montego Bay]] and [[Saint Ann Parish|St.Ann's Bay]]www/slavevoyages.org |langs = English, [[Jamaican English]], [[Jamaican Patois]] |rels = Christianity |related = [[Igbo people]], [[Igbo American]]s }} '''[[Igbo people]] in [[Jamaica]]''' were shipped by Europeans onto the island between the 18th and 19th centuries as [[Slavery in the British and French Caribbean|enslaved]] and indentured labour on plantations. Igbo people constituted a large portion of the African population enslaved people in Jamaica. Some slave censuses detailed the large number of enslaved Igbo people on various plantations throughout the island on different dates throughout the 18th century.{{cite book|title=Africa in America: Slave Acculturation and Resistance in the American South and the British Caribbean, 1736-1831 |first=Michael |last=Mullin |publisher=University of Illinois Press |page=26 |year=1995 |isbn=0-252-06446-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=so71jZ6mHBAC&pg=PA26}} Their presence was a large part in forming Jamaican culture, Igbo cultural influence remains in [[List of African words in Jamaican Patois#Igbo language|language]], dance, music, folklore, cuisine, religion and mannerisms. In Jamaica the Igbo were often referred to as Eboe or Ibo.{{cite news|title=Petticoat-Rebellion |publisher=''Jamaica Observer'' |date=August 6, 2001 |url=http://www.jamaicaobserver.com/magazines/allwoman/12276_-Petticoat-Rebellion--}} There are a substantial number of [[Igbo language|Igbo languge]] [[Loanword|loanwords]] in [[Jamaican Patois]], however the majority of African loanwords in Jamaican Patois are from the [[Akan language]] of modern-day [[Ghana]].Cassidy FG: Multiple etymologies in Jamaican Creole. Am Speech 1966, 41:211-215 Igbo people mostly populated the northwestern section of the island. {{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} ==History== {{Igbo people}} Originating primarily from what was known as the [[Bight of Bonny|Bight of Biafra]] on the West African coast, Igbo people were taken in relatively high numbers to Jamaica as a result of the [[Atlantic slave trade|Transatlantic Slave Trade]], beginning around 1750. The primary ports from which the majority of these enslaved people were taken from were [[Bonny, Nigeria|Bonny]] and [[Calabar]], two port towns that are now in south-eastern Nigeria.{{cite book|title=Trans-Atlantic Dimensions of Ethnicity in the African Diaspora |first1=Paul E. |last1=Lovejoy |pages=85–86 |first2=David Vincent |last2=Trotman |publisher=Continuum International Publishing Group |year=2003 |isbn=0-8264-4907-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=nSOyBs14tHEC&pg=PA85}} The [[Slave ship|slave ships]] arriving from [[Bristol]] and [[Liverpool]] delivered the slaves to British colonies including Jamaica. The bulk of enslaved Igbo people arrived relatively late, between 1790 and 1807, when the British passed the [[Slave Trade Act 1807|Abolition of the Slave Trade Act]] which outlawed the slave trade in the British Empire.{{cite book|title=Encyclopedia of Jamaican Heritage |first=Olive |last=Senior |authorlink=Olive Senior|publisher=Twin Guinep Publishers |year=2003 |isbn=976-8007-14-1}} Jamaica, after [[History of slavery in Virginia|Virginia]], was the second most common disembarkation point for slave ships arriving from the Bight of Biafra.{{cite book|title=Murder at Montpelier: Igbo Africans in Virginia |first=Douglas B. |last=Chambers |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |pages=14, 159 |year=2009 |isbn=1-60473-246-6}} Igbo people were spread on plantations on the island's northwestern side, specifically the areas around [[Montego Bay]] and [[Saint Ann Parish|St. Ann's Bay]],{{cite book|title=Routes to Slavery: Direction, Ethnicity, and Mortality in the Transatlantic Slave Trade |first1=David |last1=Eltis |first2=David |last2=Richardson |publisher=Routledge |page=83 |year=1997 |isbn=0-7146-4820-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kuXEzQZQmawC&pg=PA83}} and consequently, their influence was concentrated there. The region also witnessed a number of revolts that were attributed to people of Igbo origin. Slave owner Matthew Lewis spent time in Jamaica between 1815 and 1817 and studied the way his slaves organised themselves by ethnicity and he noted, for example, that at one time when he "went down to the negro-houses to hear the whole body of Eboes lodge a complaint against one of the book-keepers".{{cite book|title=Routes to Slavery |first1=David |last1=Eltis |first2=David |last2=Richardson |publisher= |year=1997 |pages=73–74 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kuXEzQZQmawC&pg=PA73 |isbn=}} [[Olaudah Equiano]], a prominent member of the movement for the abolition of the slave trade, was an African-born Igbo ex-slave. On one of his journeys to the Americas as a free man, as documented in his 1789 [[The Interesting Narrative of the Life of Olaudah Equiano|journal]], Equiano was hired by a Dr. Charles Irving to recruit slaves for his 1776 [[Mosquito Shore]] scheme in Jamaica, for which Equiano hired Igbo slaves, whom he called "My own countrymen". Equiano was especially useful to Irving for his knowledge of the [[Igbo language]], using Equiano as a tool to maintain social order among his Igbo slaves in Jamaica.{{cite journal|title=Slavery and Abolition |first=Paul E. |last=Lovejoy |pages=15–16 |publisher=Routledge |volume=27 |issue=3 |date=December 2006 |url=http://www2.bakersfieldcollege.edu/gdumler/English%205A/Articles%20for%205A/Equiano%20Autobiography%20Memory.pdf |format=PDF}} Igbo slaves were known, many a times, to have resorted to resistance rather than revolt and maintained "unwritten rules of the plantation" of which the plantation owners were forced to abide by.{{cite book|title=Martha Brae's Two Histories: European Expansion and Caribbean Culture-building in Jamaica |first=Jean |last=Besson |page=43 |publisher=UNC Press Books |year=2002 |isbn=0-8078-5409-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6FRaHpZbQ3wC&pg=PA43}} Igbo culture influenced Jamaican spirituality with the introduction of [[Obeah]] folk magic; accounts of "Eboe" slaves being "obeahed" by each other have been documented by plantation owners. However, it is more likely that the word "Obeah" was also used by enslaved [[Akan people|Akan]] people, before Igbos arrived in Jamaica. Other Igbo cultural influences include the [[Jonkonnu]] festivals, Igbo words such as "unu", "una", idioms, and proverbs in [[Jamaican Patois|Jamaican patois]]. In [[Jamaican Maroons|Maroon]] music were songs derived from specific African ethnic groups, among these were songs called "Ibo" that had a distinct style.{{cite book|title="Rock It Come Over": The Folk Music of Jamaica |first=Olive |last=Lewin |page=156 |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |year=2000 |isbn=976-640-028-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hqFTA32bLbsC&pg=PA156}} Igbo people were hardly reported to have been Maroons. Enslaved Igbo people were known to have committed mass suicides, not only for rebellion, but in the belief their spirits will return to their motherland.{{cite book|title=The Trickster Comes West: Pan-African Influence in Early Black Diasporan Narratives |first=Babacar |last=M'Baye |page=214 |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |year=2009 |isbn=1-60473-233-4}} In a publication of a 1791 issue of ''[[Massachusetts Magazine]]'', an anti-slavery poem was published called ''Monimba'', which depicted a fictional pregnant enslaved Igbo woman who committed suicide on a slave ship bound for Jamaica. The poem is an example of the stereotype of enslaved Igbo people in the Americas.{{cite book|title=American Elegy: The Poetry of Mourning from the Puritans to Whitman |first=Max |last=Cavitch |page=215 |publisher=University of Minnesota Press |year=2007 |isbn=0-8166-4893-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QPFvDyzYurkC&pg=PA215}}{{cite book|title=The Origins of African American Literature, 1680-1865 |first=Dickson D. |last=Bruce |page=67 |publisher=University of Virginia Press |year=2001 |isbn=0-8139-2067-1 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lNFxok6gBD0C&pg=PA67}} Igbo slaves were also distinguished physically by a prevalence of "yellowish" skin tones prompting the colloquialisms "red eboe" used to describe people with light skin tones and African features.{{cite book|title=A Dictionary of Jamaican English |first=Frederic Gomes |edition=2nd |last=Cassidy |author2=Robert Brock Le Page |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |year=2002 |isbn=976-640-127-6 |page=457}} Enslaved Igbo women were paired with enslaved [[Coromantee]] ([[Akan people|Akan]]) men by slave owners so as to subdue the latter due to the belief that Igbo women were bound to their first-born sons' birthplace. {{cite book|title=Africa in America: |first= |last=Mullin |publisher= |year=1995 |isbn= |page=26 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=so71jZ6mHBAC&pg=PA26}} Archibald Monteith, whose birth name was Aneaso, was an enslaved Igbo man taken to Jamaica after being tricked by an African slave trader. Anaeso wrote a journal about his life, from when he was kidnapped from [[Igboland]] to when he became a Christian convert.{{cite book|last=Warner Lewis|first=Maureen|title=Archibald Monteath: Igbo, Jamaican, Moravian|year=2007|publisher=[[University of the West Indies Press]]|location=[[Kingston, Jamaica]]|isbn=9789766401979|pages=400}} After the [[Slavery Abolition Act 1833|abolition of slavery]] in Jamaica in the 1830s, Igbo people also arrived on the island as [[Indentured servitude|indentured servants]] between the years of 1840 and 1864 along with a majority [[Kongo people|Kongo]] and "Nago" ([[Yoruba people|Yoruba]]) people.{{cite book|title=Jamaica in Slavery and Freedom: History, Heritage and Culture |first1=Kathleen E. A. |last1=Monteith |first2=Glen |last2=Richards |page=90 |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |year=2002 |isbn=976-640-108-X}} Since the 19th century most of the population [[Afro-Jamaican|African Jamaicans]] had assimilated into the wider Jamaican society and have largely dropped ethnic associations with Africa.{{Citation needed|date=April 2018}} ===Slave rebellions and uprisings=== Enslaved Igbo people, along with "Angolas" and "Congoes" were often runaways, liberating themselves from enslavement. In slave runaway advertisements held in Jamaica workhouses in 1803 out of 1046 Africans recorded, 284 were described as "Eboes and Mocoes", 185 "Congoes", 259 "Angolas", 101 "Mandingoes", 70 [[Coromantees]], 60 "Chamba" of [[Sierra Leone]], 57 "Nagoes and Pawpaws" and 30 "scattering". 187 were documentined as "unclassified" and 488 were "American born negroes and mulattoes".{{cite book|title=American Negro Slavery - A Survey of the Supply, Employment and Control of Negro Labor as Determined by the Plantation Regime |first=Ulrich Bonnell |last=Phillips |page=44 |publisher=Read Books |year=2010 |isbn=1-4455-3770-2 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zlZ7iT2HB2kC&pg=PA44}} Some notable slave rebellions involving Igbo people include: *The 1815 Igbo conspiracy in Jamaica's [[Saint Elizabeth Parish]], which involved around 250 enslaved Igbo people,{{cite book|title=Olaudah Equiano and the Igbo World: History, Society and Atlantic Diaspora Connections |first=Chima Jacob |last=Korieh |publisher=Africa World Press |page=364 |year=2009 |isbn=1-59221-664-1}} described as one of the revolts that contributed to a climate for [[Abolitionism in the United Kingdom|abolition]].{{cite book|title=African Voices of the Atlantic Slave Trade: Beyond the Silence and the Shame |first=Anne Caroline |last=Bailey |page=98 |publisher=Beacon Press |year=2005 |isbn=0-8070-5512-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=YrIjNMu5_vsC&pg=PA98}} A letter by the Governor of [[Manchester Parish]] to Bathurst on April 13, 1816,{{cite book|title=Documents on British West Indian History, 1807-1833 |author=[[Eric Eustace Williams]] |publisher=Trinidad Pub. Co |year=1952}} quoted the leaders of the rebellion on trial as saying "that 'he had all the Eboes in his hand', meaning to insinuate that all the Negroes from that Country were under his controul".{{cite book|title=Slaves who Abolished Slavery: Blacks in Rebellion |first=Richard |last=Hart |authorlink=Richard Hart (Jamaican historian and politician)|page=226 |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |year=2002 |isbn=976-640-110-1}} The plot was thwarted and several slaves were executed. *The 1816 [[Black River, Jamaica|Black River]] rebellion plot, was according to Lewis (1834:227—28), carried out by only people of "Eboe" origin.{{cite book|title=Afro-Creole: Power, Opposition, and Play in the Caribbean |first=Richard D. E. |last=Burton |page=84 |publisher=Cornell University Press |year=1997 |isbn=0-8014-8325-5 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=O06PhHXMJM0C&pg=PA84}} This plot was uncovered on March 22, 1816, by a novelist and absentee planter named Matthew Gregory "Monk" Lewis. Lewis recorded what Hayward (1985) called a proto-[[Calypso music|Calypso]] revolutionary hymn, sung by a group of Igbo slaves, led by the "King of the Eboes". They sang:
Oh me Good friend, Mr. Wilberforce, make we free!
God Almighty thank ye! God Almighty thank ye!
God Almighty, make we free!
Buckra in this country no make we free:
What Negro for to do? What Negro for to do?
Take force by force! Take force by force!{{cite book|title=Out of Slavery: Abolition and After |first=Jack Ernest Shalom |last=Hayward |page=110 |publisher=Routledge |year=1985 |isbn=0-7146-3260-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D2S2CLgceMMC&pg=PA110}}
:"Mr. Wilberforce" was in reference to [[William Wilberforce]] a British politician wo was a leader of the movement to abolish the slave trade. "Buckra" was a term introduced by Igbo and [[Efik people|Efik]] slaves in Jamaica to refer to [[white people|white]] slave owners and overseers.{{cite book|title=Hog & Hominy: Soul Food from Africa to America |first=Frederick Douglass |last=Opie |publisher=Columbia University Press |year=2008 |page=17 |isbn=0-231-14638-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9lAl8f11qngC&pg=PA17}} ==Culture== Among Igbo cultural items in Jamaica were the Eboe, or Ibo drums popular throughout all of Jamaican music.{{cite book|title=Jamaica the Culture |first=Amber |last=Wilson |page=22 |publisher=Crabtree Publishing Company |year=2004 |isbn=0-7787-9332-X}} Food was also influenced, for example the Igbo word "mba" meaning "yam root" was used to describe a type of [[yam (vegetable)|yam]] in Jamaica called "himba".{{cite book|title=English: History, Diversity, and Change |first1=David |last1=Graddol |first2=Dick |last2=Leith |first3=Joan |last3=Swann |page=210 |publisher=Routledge |year=1996 |isbn=0-415-13117-0}}{{cite book|title=African Continuities in the Linguistic Heritage of Jamaica |first=Maureen Warner |last=Lewis |publisher=African Caribbean Institute of Jamaica |page=24 |year=1996}} Igbo and Akan slaves affected drinking culture among the black population in Jamaica, using alcohol in ritual and libation. In Igboland as well as on the [[Gold Coast (region)|Gold Coast]], [[palm wine]] was used on these occasions and had to be substituted by [[rum]] in Jamaica because of the absence of palm wine.{{cite book|title=Drinking: Anthropological Approaches |first1=I. de |last1=Garine |first2=Valérie de |last2=Garine |publisher=Berghahn Books |pages=221–222 |year=2001 |isbn=1-57181-809-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=PdCJjFrxMewC&pg=PA222}} [[Jonkonnu]], a parade that is held in many West Indian nations, has been attributed to the [[Njoku Ji]] "yam-spirit cult", Okonko and [[Ekpe]] of the Igbo. Several masquerades of the [[Kalabari people|Kalabari]] and Igbo have similar appearance to those of Jonkonnu masquerades.{{cite book|title=Murder at Montpelier |first=Douglas B. |last=Chambers |page=182 |date= 2005 |isbn=}} ===Language=== Much of Jamaican mannerisms and gestures themselves have a wider African origin, rather than specific Igbo origin. Some examples are non-verbal actions such as "[[sucking-teeth]]" known in Igbo as "ima osu" or "imu oso" and "cutting-eye" known in Igbo as "iro anya", and other non-verbal communications by eye movements.{{cite book|title=Jamaica in Slavery and Freedom: History, Heritage and Culture |first1=Kathleen E. A. |last1=Monteith |first2=Glen |last2=Richards |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |year=2002 |isbn=976-640-108-X |page=114 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=OjdvvGAnsx0C&pg=PA114}} There are a few Igbo words in Jamaican Patois that resulted when slaves were restricted from speaking their own languages. These Igbo words still exist in Jamaican vernacular, including words such as "unu" meaning "you (plural)", "di" meaning "to be (in state of)", which became "de", and "Okwuru" "Okra" a vegetable.{{cite book | title=The Missing Spanish Creoles: Recovering the Birth of Plantation Contact Languages | first=John H. | last=McWhorter| isbn=0-520-21999-6 |page=128 | publisher=University of California Press | year=2000}} Some words of Igbo origin are * "akara", from "''àkàrà"'', type of food, also from Ewe and Yoruba;{{Harvcoltxt|Cassidy|2002|p=4}} * "attoo", from "''átú" meaning'' "chewing stick".{{Harvcoltxt|Cassidy|2002|p=14}} Idiom such as, via [[Gullah language|Gullah]] "big eye" from Igbo "anya ukwu" meaning "greedy";{{Harvcoltxt|Cassidy|2002|p=41}}{{Harvcoltxt|Holloway|2005|p=94}}{{Harvcoltxt|Bartens|2003|p=150}} * "breechee" from "''mbùríchì"'', an [[Kingdom of Nri|Nri-Igbo]] nobleman;{{Harvcoltxt|Cassidy|2002|p=68}} * "de", from "''dị"'' [with adverbial] "is" ''(to be)'';{{Harvcoltxt|McWhorter|2000|p=128}}{{Harvcoltxt|Rickford|Romain|Sato|1999|p=137}} * "[[obeah]]" from "''ọbiạ" meaning'' "doctoring""mysticism";{{Harvcoltxt|Eltis|1997|p=88}} * "[[okra]]" from "''ọkwurụ"'', a vegetable; * "poto-poto" from "opoto-opoto", * "''mkpọtọ-mkpọtọ" meaning'' "mud" or "muddy", also from Akan; * "Ibo","Eboe", from "''Ị̀gbò"'', {{Harvcoltxt|Cassidy|2002|p=378}} * "se", from "''sị"'', "quote follows", also from Akan "''se"'' and English "''say"'';{{Harvcoltxt|Menz|2008|p=12}} * "soso", from ''sọsọ'' "only";{{Harvcoltxt|Huber|Parkvall|1999|p=47}}" * unu" or "una" from "''únù"'' meaning "you (plural)"{{Harvcoltxt|Cassidy|2002|p=457}} ===Proverbs=== ''"Ilu"'' in Igbo means proverbs,{{cite book|title=Of Minstrelsy and Masks: The Legacy of Ezenwa-Ohaeto in Nigerian Writing |editor-first1=Christine |editor-last1=Matzke |publisher=Rodopi |page=147 |year=2006 |isbn=90-420-2168-3 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=W_RQNoVnMPoC&pg=PA147}} a part of language that is very important to the Igbo. Igbo proverbs crossed the Atlantic along with the masses of enslaved Igbo people. Several translated Igbo proverbs survive in Jamaica today because of the Igbo ancestors. Some of these include: *'''Igbo''': "He who will swallow udala seeds must consider the size of his anus" :'''Jamaican''': "Cow must know 'ow 'im bottom stay before 'im swallow abbe [Twi 'palm nut'] seed"; "Jonkro must know what 'im a do before 'im swallow abbe seed." * '''Igbo''': "Where are the young suckers that will grow when the old banana tree dies?" :'''Jamaican''' "When plantain wan' dead, it shoot [sends out new suckers]." * '''Igbo''': "A man who makes trouble for other is also making one for himself." :'''Jamaican''': "When you dig a hole/ditch for one, dig two." * '''Igbo''': "The fly who has no one to advise it follows the corpse into the ground." :'''Jamaican''': "Sweet-mout' fly follow coffin go a hole"; "Idle donkey follow cane-bump [the cart with cane cuttings] go a [animal] pound"; "Idle donkey follow crap-crap [food scraps] till dem go a pound [waste dump]." * '''Igbo''': "The sleep that lasts for one market day to another has become death." :'''Jamaican''': "Take sleep mark death [Sleep is foreshadowing of death]." ==Religion== "[[Obeah]]" refers to folk magic and sorcery that was derived from West African sources. The [[W. E. B. Du Bois Institute]] database{{cite book|title=The River Flows On: Black Resistance, Culture, and Identity Formation in Early America |first=Walter C. |last=Rucker |publisher=LSU Press |page=40 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=c2XlG4rRK4QC&pg=PA40 |year=2006 |isbn=0-8071-3109-1}} supports obeah being traced to the "''dibia"'' or "''obia" meaning "doctoring"'' traditions of the Igbo people.{{cite dictionary|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/obeah |title=Obeah |publisher=[[Merriam-Webster|Merriam Webster]] |accessdate=2010-06-03}}{{cite book|title=Murder at Montpelier: Igbo Africans in Virginia |first=Douglas B. |last=Chambers |publisher=University Press of Mississippi |year=2009 |pages=14, 36 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=vqpoxEl_0_4C&pg=PA36 |isbn=1-60473-246-6}} Specialists in "Obia" (also spelled ''Obea'') were known as "Dibia" (doctor, psychic) practiced similarly as the obeah men and women of the Caribbean, like predicting the future and manufacturing charms.{{cite book|title=Routes to Slavery|first1=David |last1=Eltis |first2=David |last2=Richardson |publisher= |year=1997 |page=88 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kuXEzQZQmawC&pg=PA88 |isbn=}}{{cite book|title=Fighting for Honor: The History of African Martial Art Traditions in the Atlantic World |first1=M. |first2=Thomas |last1=J. |last2=Desch-Obi |publisher=University of South Carolina Press |year=2008 |page=58 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HNYwa1VeLIIC&pg=PA58 |isbn=1-57003-718-3}} In Jamaican mythology, "River Mumma", a mermaid, is linked to "Oya" of the [[Yoruba religion|Yoruba]] and "Uhamiri/Idemili" of the [[Odinani|Igbo]].{{cite book|title=Stepping Forward: Black Women in Africa and the Americas |first1=Catherine |last1=Higgs |first2=Barbara A. |last2=Moss |first3=Earline Rae |last3=Ferguson |page=102 |publisher=Ohio University Press |year=2002 |isbn=0-8214-1455-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Dd00m5JrFhMC&pg=PA102}} Among Igbo beliefs in Jamaica was the idea of Africans being able to fly back home to Africa.{{cite book|title=Antebellum Slave Narratives: Cultural and Political Expressions of Africa |first=Jermaine O. |last=Archer |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=2009 |page=67 |isbn=0-415-99027-0 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Jw3Vruv6zJwC&pg=PA67}} There were reports by Europeans who visited and lived in Jamaica that Igbo slaves believed they would return to their country after death.{{cite book|title=Routes to Slavery |first1=David |last1=Eltis |first2=David |last2=Richardson |publisher= |page=73 |year=1997 |isbn= |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kuXEzQZQmawC&pg=PA73}} ==Notable Jamaicans of Igbo descent== [[File:Grave of Archibald Monteith, Carmel Moravian Church, Jamaica, 1968.png|thumb|alt=A picture of Archibald Monteith's grave in Jamaica, he was an Igbo taken to Jamaica as a slave|Archibald Monteith's grave. He was an Igbo known as Aneaso and was taken to Jamaica as a slave.]] *Archibald Monteith, an ex-slave who was called "Aneaso" born in Africa, and brought to Jamaica and later wrote an autobiography *One of [[Malcolm Gladwell]]'s European ancestors had a child by an Igbo slave, which started off the mixed-race Ford family on Gladwell's mothers side.{{cite book|title=Faces of America: How 12 Extraordinary People Discovered Their Pasts |first=Henry Louis|last=Gates |authorlink=Henry Louis Gates|page=178 |publisher=NYU Press |year=2010 |isbn=0-8147-3264-X |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=meYbj1E6Ki8C&pg=PA178}} ==See also== {{portal|Jamaica|Igbo}} *[[Jamaicans of African ancestry]] *[[Redbone (ethnicity)]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Bibliography== *{{cite book | title=The Missing Spanish Creoles: Recovering the Birth of Plantation Contact Languages | first=John H. | last=McWhorter| isbn=0-520-21999-6 | url=https://books.google.com/books?id=czFufZI4Zx4C | publisher=University of California Press | year=2000}} *{{cite book|title=English: history, diversity, and change |first1=David |last1=Graddol |first2=Dick |last2=Leith |first3=Joan |last3=Swann |publisher=Routledge |year=1996 |isbn=0-415-13117-0}} *{{cite book|title=A contrastive grammar: Islander - Caribbean Standard English - Spanish |first=Ángela |last=Bartens |publisher=Finnish Academy of Science and Letters |year=2003 |isbn=951-41-0940-6}} *{{cite book|title=A Dictionary of Jamaican English |first=Frederic Gomes |edition=2nd |last=Cassidy |author2=Robert Brock Le Page |publisher=University of the West Indies Press |year=2002 |isbn=976-640-127-6 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_lmFzFgsTZYC}} *{{cite book|title=London Jamaican-Jamaican Creole in London |first=Jessica |last=Menz |publisher=GRIN Verlag |year=2008 |isbn=3-638-94849-8}} *{{cite book|title=Africanisms in American culture |first=Joseph E. |last=Holloway |publisher=Indiana University Press |year=2005 |isbn=0-253-21749-0}} *{{cite book|title=Creole genesis, attitudes and discourse: studies celebrating Charlene J. Sato |first1=John R. |last1=Rickford |first2=Suzanne |last2=Romaine |first3=Charlene J. |last3=Sato |publisher=John Benjamins Publishing Company |year=1999 |isbn=90-272-5242-4}} *{{cite book|title=African continuities in the linguistic heritage of Jamaica |first=Maureen Warner |last=Lewis |publisher=African Caribbean Institute of Jamaica |year=1996}} *{{cite book|title=Routes to slavery: direction, ethnicity, and mortality in the transatlantic slave trade |first1=David |last1=Eltis |first2=David |last2=Richardson |publisher=Routledge |year=1997 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=kuXEzQZQmawC |isbn=0-7146-4820-5}} *{{cite book|title=Spreading the word: the issue of diffusion among the Atlantic Creoles |first1=Magnus |last1=Huber |first2=Mikael |last2=Parkvall |publisher=University of Westminster Press |year=1999 |isbn=1-85919-093-6}} {{Demographics of Jamaica}} {{Igbo topics}} {{African diaspora}} [[Category:Jamaican culture]] [[Category:Languages of Jamaica]] [[Category:Jamaica-related lists|African words in Jamaican Patois]] [[Category:Lists of loanwords|Jamaican Patois]] [[Category:Afro-Jamaican]] [[Category:Igbo diaspora]] [[Category:Jamaican people of Igbo descent| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Jamaica]] [[Category:Jamaican people]] [[Category:History of Jamaica]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox organization | name = International Association for Engineering Geology and the Environment | former name = International Association for Engineering Geology | image = Logo of the IAEG association.jpg | image_border = | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | abbreviation = IAEG | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = {{Start date|1964}}
| type = NGO | status = | purpose = Scientific and professional association | headquarters = | location = | coords = | region_served = | membership = 3798<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iaeg.info/info/iaeg-in-the-world/|title=IAEG in the World - IAEG|website=iaeg.info|language=en|access-date=2018-06-07}}</ref> | leader_title = President | leader_name = Prof. Scott F. Burns | general = Prof. Faquan Wu | key_people = Jean-Alain Fleurisson, Giorgio Lollino, Rafig Azzam, Maria Heloisa Barros De Oliveira Frascá, Jeffrey R. Keaton, Mark Eggers, Yogendra Deva, Louis Van Rooy, Carlos Delgado, Martin Culshaw | main_organ = Council | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | affiliations = [[International Union of Geological Sciences]] | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = {{URL|www.iaeg.info}} }}
The '''International Association for Engineering Geology and the Environment''' ({{lang-fr|Association Internationale de Géologie de I'lngénieur et de l'Environnement}}), formerly '''International Association for Engineering Geology''',<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The International Association for Engineering Geology and the Environment: 50 years|last=Delgado et al. (eds.)|first=|publisher=Science Press|year=2014|isbn=978-7-03-040706-1|location=Beijing|pages=}}</ref> also known as '''IAEG''' ({{lang-fr|AIGI}}),<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://iaeg.info/media/1008/iaeg-statutes.pdf|title=The statute of IAEG|last=|first=|date=|website=www.iaeg.info|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=5 June 2018}}</ref> is an international scientific society which was founded in 1964.<ref name="IAEGE">{{cite web |url=http://www.iaeg.info/ |title=International Association for Engineering Geology and the Environment. |format= |work= |accessdate=2009-05-23}}</ref> It is affiliated with the [[International Union of Geological Sciences]] (IUGS) and has 3,798 members<ref name=":4">{{Cite web|url=http://iaeg.info/info/iaeg-in-the-world/|title=IAEG in the World - IAEG|website=iaeg.info|language=en|access-date=2018-06-08}}</ref> and 59 national groups all over the world.
The association aims to promote and encourage the advancement of [[engineering geology]] through technological activities and research. At the same time it strives to improve teaching and training in engineering geology, and to collect, evaluate and disseminate the results of engineering geological activities.<ref name="About">{{cite web|url=http://www.iaeg.info/AboutIAEG/tabid/55/Default.aspx |title=About IAEG |format= |work= |accessdate=2009-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301061824/http://iaeg.info/AboutIAEG/tabid/55/Default.aspx |archivedate=2009-03-01 |df= }}</ref> Together with [[Springer Science+Business Media]], it publishes the ''[[Bulletin of Engineering Geology and the Environment]]''.<ref name="Springer">{{cite web |url=https://www.springer.com/earth+sciences/journal/10064 |title=Bulletin of Engineering Geology and the Environment |format= |work= |accessdate=2009-05-23}}</ref><ref name="IAEG">{{cite web|url=http://www.iaeg.info/Bulletin/tabid/56/Default.aspx |title=International Association of Engineering Geology and the Environment - Bulletin |format= |work= |accessdate=2009-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090430113229/http://www.iaeg.info/Bulletin/tabid/56/Default.aspx |archivedate=2009-04-30 |df= }}</ref>
The first president of the IAEG was [[Asher Shadmon]], who held the office from 1964 to 1968. The current president is Scott F. Burns from [[Portland State University]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iaeg.info/info/board/|title=Board - IAEG|website=iaeg.info|language=en|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref>
Every two years, the IAEG awards the ''[[Hans Cloos#The Hans Cloos medal|Hans Cloos]]'' medal to an engineering geologist of outstanding merit.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://iaeg.info/info/awards-and-prizes/hans-cloos-medal/|title=Hans-Cloos Medal - IAEG|website=iaeg.info|language=en|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://australiangeomechanics.org/awards/hans-cloos-medal-iaeg/|title=Hans Cloos Medal (IAEG) – Australian Geomechanics Society|website=australiangeomechanics.org|language=en|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> Every four years, the IAEG organizes an international congress, during which a general meeting of the association takes place and the board for the subsequent four years is also elected.<ref name=":0" /> The ''XII IAEG Congress'' was held in [[Turin]] (Italy) in September 2014.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.iaeg2014.com/|title=iaeg2014|website=www.iaeg2014.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> The ''XIII IAEG Congress'' will be held in [[San Francisco]] (California, USA), in September 2018,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.aegannualmeeting.org/|title=AEG Annual Meeting|website=AEG Annual Meeting|language=en|access-date=2018-06-05}}</ref> and will also serve as the 61st annual meeting of the [[Association of Environmental & Engineering Geologists]].
== History ==
=== The birth of the IAEG === During the XXII [[International Geological Congress]] (IGS) in New Delhi, on 12 December 1964, the Israeli geologist [[Asher Shadmon]] remarked that ''"quarry materials and mineral products used in engineering"'' were not being discussed and proposed that the IUGS should create and fund an international permanent commission dedicated to that topic. Other geologists at the congress suggested that the commission should cover also the relationship between the materials in their natural place and the work of engineers.
On 17 December the assembly voted the following motion unanimously: ''"It is recommended that a distinct Commission of "Engineering Geology" should be established in the context of International Geological Congresses.[…] The objective of the Commission and its Sub-commissions would be to promote the knowledge and dissemination of appropriate information, gather ´case-histories´, prepare literature reviews and relevant catalogues, provide information on completed or ongoing research, gather statistical geological data on the industries and determine the list of further research required"''.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Arnould|first=Marcel|date=1970|title=The International Association of Engineering Geology. History - Activity.|url=|journal=Bulletin of the IAEG|location=Paris|volume=1|pages=22–28|via=}}</ref><ref name=":3">{{Cite news|url=|title=30th anniversary of the IAEG / 30ème anniversaire de l’AIGI: Evolution of the IAEG life, Engineering geology as an independent science.|last=Shadmon|first=Asher|date=1994|work=IAEG Newsletter|access-date=|location=Paris|volume=21|page=3}}</ref>
On 19 December, although the interest in engineering geology was high, due to scarcity of resources that did not allow to support a new permanent commission, the executive committee of the IUGS proposed to create a small committee, headed by Shadmon, in charge of producing and presenting a report on the state of the situation by contacting the [[International Society for Soil Mechanics and Geotechnical Engineering|International Society for Soil Mechanics]] and the [[International Society for Rock Mechanics]], as well as existing national societies of engineering geology.
However on 21 December the delegates decided to immediately hold a new session during which the ''International Association for Engineering Geology'' (IAEG) was unanimously created. Besides Asher Shadmon, the founding members were Marcel Arnould (France), G. Bain (USA), M.S. Balasundaram (India), L.M.C. Calembert (Belgium), R.S. Chaturvedi (India), G.C. Chowdhary (India), E. Beneo (Italy), K. Erguvanli (Turkey), A. Hamza (India), M.S. Jain (India), L.E. Kent (South Africa), V.S. Krishnaswamy (India), J.D.S. Lakshmaman (France), A.R. Mahendra (India), M. Manfredi (Italy), V. Prasad (India), B. Ramchandran (India), J.Th. Rosenqvist (Norway), B. Sanatkumar (India), P.B. Srinivasan (India), L.S. Srivastava (India) and M. Zapata (Spain). They elected a provisional committee to steer the initial activity.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" />
=== The first years === At the beginning, the association worked on enhancing the provisional committee to gain full international representation. By the end of 1966, the committee was composed as follows: Asher Shadmon (Israel), as President; Marcel Arnould (France), as Secretary; E. Beneo (Italy); V.S. Krishnaswamy, R.S. Mithal and M.S. Balasundaram (India); K. Erguvanli (Turkey); A.M. Hull (USA), president of the American Association of Engineering Geologist; E.M. Sergeev and N.V. Kolomenskij (USSR); Quido Záruba (Czechoslovakia); M.D. Ruiz (Brazil); G. Champetier de Ribes (France), as Treasurer. Discussions to join the IAEG were still ongoing with representatives of Australia, Japan and Mexico.<ref name=":2" />
During the first two years the first statutes were established and a programme of the activities was defined. The purposes and goals of the association were defined as follows: ''"Article 1: The scope of engineering geology covers the applications of earth sciences to engineering, planning, construction, prospecting, testing and processing of related materials"; "Article 2: The aims of the IAEG are to encourage'' ''research, training and dissemination of knowledge by developing the international cooperation in its relation to engineering".''<ref name=":2" />
At the 1967 meeting of the IUGS, a request of affiliation of the IAEG to the IUGS was presented and accepted by the executive committee. The decision was ratified unanimously by the general assembly of the IUGS on 23 August 1968 in Prague.<ref name=":2" />
=== The first general assembly === The input from the Czechoslovakian engineering geologist has been noticeable in the first years, especially that of Quido Záruba and Jaroslav Pasek. They were together responsible for organizing a section on engineering geology at the XXIII International Geological Congress (IGC) in Prague in 1968, at which they shared the aims of the IAEG. They also organised the first scientific symposium of the IAEG in Brno (Czechoslovakia), from 26 to 27 April 1968 and a second symposium during the IGC on ''"Engineering geology and land planning"''.<ref name=":2" />
The first general assembly was held on 23 August 1968 in Prague during the XXIII IGC. At the time of the congress, the country was deeply affected by the movement of soviet troops. Nevertheless, the general assembly went ahead and the statutes were ratified and an executive committee was elected for a period of four years to replace the provisional committee.<ref name=":2" />
The new committee was composed as follows: Quido Záruba (Czechoslovakia), President; Marcel Arnould (France), Secretary General; G. Champetier de Ribes (France), Treasurer; Asher Shadmon (Israel), Past President; L. Calembert (Belgium), Vice-president for Europe; L. Cluff (USA), Vice-president for North America; M.D. Ruiz (Brazil), Vice-president for South America; L. Oborn (New Zealand), vice president for Australasia; H. Tanaka (Japan), Vice-president for Asia; a representative from Ghana as Vice-president for Africa. Other members: N.V. Kolomenskij (USSR); A Nemock (Czechoslovakia); J. Janjic (Yugoslavia); R. Glossop (United Kingdom); A. Drucker (Federal Republic of Germany); J.M. Crepeau (Canada).<ref name=":2" />
In addition to the executive committee, three "working groups" were established:
# Landslides, under the responsibility of J. Pasek (Czechoslovakia); # Soluble rocks, under the responsibility of F. Reuter (East Germany) and K. Erguvanli (Turkey); # Geotechnical mapping, under the responsibility of M. Matula (Czechoslovakia).
Finally, it was decided to organize future congresses specifically for the IAEG and to hold these alternately with the International Geological Congresses, which means that both events would take place every four years but the IAEG would have a congress with a general assembly every two years and scientific symposia in the years in between.<ref name=":1" />
The first congresses with general assemblies were as follows:
* New Dehli (India) XXII IGC in 1964 * Prague (Czechoslovakia) XXIII IGC in 1968; * Paris (France) 1st IAEG congress in 1970.
=== The Bulletin of the IAEG === The first elected executive committee decided in their second meeting at the UNESCO Palace in Paris (May 1969) to create a journal of the IAEG, to be edited and published by the Association and called the [[Bulletin of Engineering Geology and the Environment|Bulletin of the IAEG]] (full name: ''"Bulletin of the International Association of Engineering Geology - Bulletin de l'Association Internationale de Géologie de l'Ingénieur"'').
The first edition of the Bulletin was distributed during the first IAEG congress in September 1970 in Paris. This was possible thanks to the personal efforts of Quido Záruba, the IAEG president, J. Pasek, Marcel Arnould and several other staff from the [[Mines ParisTech|Paris School of Mines]]. Starting as a simple artisanal publication, the Bulletin became a scientific reference among the most respected journals in the fields of engineering geology, the environment and other geosciences, and "the official journal of the IAEG". It is now published by [[Springer Science+Business Media]] and edited by the Association, and goes with the title ''Bulletin of Engineering Geology and the Environment.''<ref name=":1" />
=== The second statutes === As a result of the progressive involvement of engineering geologists in consulting, in the study, design, construction and supervision of large projects and in the assessment and remediation of environmental issues, an update of the first statutes of the association was deemed necessary. The second statutes were approved by the general assembly in Kyoto (Japan) in 1992.
A new definition of [[engineering geology]] was given, which reflected the experience collected during the previous 25 years and read as follows: ''“Engineering geology is a science devoted to the investigation, study and solution of engineering and environmental problems which may arise as the result of the interaction between geology and the works and activities of man as well as to the prediction of and the development of measures for prevention or remediation of geologic hazards. Engineering geology embraces: the definition of geomorphology, structure, stratigraphy, lithology and groundwater conditions of geological formations; the characterization of the mineralogical, physico-geomechanical, chemical and hydraulic properties of all earth materials involved in construction, resource recovery and environmental change; the assessment of the mechanical and hydrologic behaviour of soil and rock masses; the prediction of changes to the above properties with time; the determination of the parameters to be considered in the stability analysis of engineering works and of earth masses; and the improvement and maintenance of the environmental condition and of the properties of the terrain”''.<ref name=":1" />
== Members == As of May 2018, the IAEG has 3,798 members<ref name=":4" /> divided as follows:
* North America - 204 members; * South America - 102 members; * Europe - 1848 members; * Africa - 172 members; * Asia - 798 members; * Australasia - 684 members.
The IAEG has 59 national groups (+1 for the territory of Chinese Taipei):<ref name=":4" /> {| class="wikitable sortable mw-collapsible" style="margin-right: auto; border: none;" !style="width: 10em;"|Country/Territory !President !Related association !style="width: 15em;"|Website |- |{{flagicon|Canada}} Canada |Doug VanDine |The Canadian Geotechnical Society |http://www.cgs.ca/ |- |{{flagicon|USA}} USA |Eldon M. Gath |The Association of Environmental and Engineering Geologists |http://www.aegweb.org/ |- |{{flagicon|Mexico}} Mexico |Carlos Garcia Herrera | | |- |{{Flagicon|Colombia}} Colombia |Édgar E. Rodriguez Granados |Colombian Geotechnical Society |http://www.scg.org.co/ |- |{{Flagicon|Peru}} Peru |Jose E. Martinez del Carpio | | |- |{{Flagicon|Brazil}} Brazil |Adalberto Aurélio Azevedo |Association for Engineering Geology and the Environment |http://www.abge.org.br/site/ |- |{{Flagicon|Paraguay}} Paraguay |Francisco Raúl Mena Knoop |Paraguayan Geotechnical Society |http://spg.org.py/ |- |{{Flagicon|Argentina}} Argentina |Norberto Jorge Bejerman |Argentinian Association of Geology Applied to Engineering |http://asagai.org.ar/ |- |{{Flagicon|Iceland}} Iceland |Birgir jonsson | | |- |{{Flagicon|United Kingdom}} United Kingdom |Helen Reeves |The Engineering Group of the Geological Society of London (EGGS) |http://www.geolsoc.org.uk/engineering |- |{{Flagicon|Ireland}} Ireland |Michael Looby | | |- |{{Flagicon|Portugal}} Portugal |José Luís Machado do Vale |Portuguese Geotechnical Society |http://ww.spgeotecnia.pt/ |- |{{Flagicon|Spain}} Spain |Carlos Delgado | | |- |{{Flagicon|France}} France |Aline Quenez |Comité Français de Géologie de l’Ingénieur et de l’Environnement. |http://www.cfgi-geologie.fr/ |- |{{Flagicon|Belgium}} Belgium |Philippe Welter |Belgian Society for Engineering Geology and Rocks Mechanics |http://sbgimr-bvigrm.be/ |- |{{Flagicon|Netherlands}} Netherlands |Robrecht Schmitz | | |- |{{flagicon|Norway}} Norway |Guro Groeneng | | |- |{{flagicon|Sweden}} Sweden |Gunilla Franzén | | |- |{{flagicon|Finland}} Finland |Arto Koskiahde | | |- |{{flagicon|Estonia}} Estonia |Johannes Pello | | |- |{{flagicon|Lithuania}} Lithuania |Kastytis Dundulis | | |- |{{flagicon|Russia}} Russia |Victor I. Bergado |Southeast Asian Geotechnical Society |http://www.seags.ait.ac.th/ |- |{{flagicon|Vietnam}} Vietnam |Ta Duc Thinh | | |- |{{flagicon|Singapore}} Singapore |Zhiye Zhao |Society for Rock Mechanics & Engineering Geology |http://srmeg.org.sg/ |- |{{flagicon|Malaysia}} Malaysia |Zakaria Mohamad | | |- |{{flagicon|Indonesia}} Indonesia |Imam A. Sadisun | | |- |{{flagicon|Australia}} Australia |Hugo Acosta-Martinez |Australian Geomechanics Society |https://australiangeomechanics.org/ |- |{{flagicon|New Zealand}} New Zealand |Charlie Price |New Zealand Geotechnical Society |http://www.nzgs.org/ |}
== Congresses == Following is a list of the international congresses of the IAEG, which are held every four years.<ref name=":1" /> Since 1998, the congresses have a main theme, which is reflected in the denomination of the event.
* 1970 {{Flagicon|France}} Paris, 1st IAEG Congress * 1974 {{Flagicon|Brazil}} São Paulo, 2nd IAEG Congress * 1978 {{Flagicon|Spain}} Madrid, 3rd IAEG Congress * 1982 {{Flagicon|India}} New Delhi, 4rd IAEG Congress * 1986 {{Flagicon|Argentina}} Buenos Aires, 5th IAEG Congress * 1990 {{Flagicon|Netherlands}} Amsterdam, 6th IAEG Congress * 1994 {{Flagicon|Portugal}} Lisbon, 7th IAEG Congress * 1998 {{Flagicon|Canada}} Vancouver, 8th IAEG Congress, ''"A global view from the Pacific Rim"'' * 2002 {{Flagicon|South Africa}} Durban, 9th IAEG Congress, ''"Engineering geology for developing countries"'' * 2006 {{Flagicon|UK}} Nottingham, 10th IAEG Congress, ''"Engineering geology for tomorrow's cities"'' * 2010 {{Flagicon|New Zealand}} Auckland, 11th IAEG Congress, ''"Geologically active"'' * 2014 {{Flagicon|Italy}} Turin, 12th IAEG Congress, ''"Engineering geology for society and territory"'' * 2018 {{Flagicon|USA}} San Francisco, 13th IAEG Congress, ''"Engineering geology for a sustainable world"'' * 2022, ''to be announced'', 14th IAEG Congress
The IAEG organizes also regional conferences. So far, Asian regional conferences and European regional conferences have been held.
=== European regional conferences ===
* 2004 {{Flagicon|Belgium}} Liège, 1st European regional conference, ''“Professional practices and engineering geological methods”'' * 2008 {{Flagicon|Spain}} Madrid, 2nd European regional conference, ''“Cities and their underground environment”''
=== Asian regional conferences ===
* 1997 {{Flagicon|Japan}} Tokyo, 1st Asian regional conference, ''“Dam geology”'' * 1999 {{Flagicon|Malaysia}} Bangi, 2nd Asian regional conference, ''“Engineering geology: Planning for sustainable development”'' * 2001 {{Flagicon|Indonesia}} Yogyakarta, 3rd Asian regional conference, ''“Natural resources management for regional development in tropical area”'' * 2004 {{Flagicon|Hong Kong}} Hong Kong, 4th Asian regional conference, ''“Engineering geology for sustainable development in mountainous areas”'' * 2005 {{Flagicon|Nepal}} Kathmandu,5th Asian regional conference, ''“Engineering geology, hydrology, and natural disasters”'' * 2007 {{Flagicon|South Korea}} Seoul, 6th Asian regional conference, ''“Geohazard in engineering geology”'' * 2009 {{Flagicon|China}} Chengdu, 7th Asian regional conference, ''“Geological engineering problems in major construction projects”'' * 2011 {{Flagicon|India}} Bangalore, 8th Asian regional conference, ''“Underground space technology”'' * 2013 {{Flagicon|China}} Beijing, 9th Asian regional conference, ''“Global view of engineering geology and the environment”'' * 2015 {{Flagicon|Japan}} Kyoto, 10th Asian regional conference, ''"Geohazards and engineering geology"'' * 2017 {{Flagicon|Nepal}} Kathmandu, 11th Asian regional conference, ''"Engineering geology for geodisaster management''' * 2019 {{Flagicon|South Korea}} Jeju, 12th Asian regional conference

[[Category:Geology organizations]] [[Category:Geology societies]] [[Category:International environmental organizations]] [[Category:International Union of Geological Sciences|Association for Engineering Geology and the Environment]] [[Category:International scientific organizations|Association for Engineering Geology and the Environment]] [[Category:Scientific organizations established in 1964]]

[[File:Landschaft bei Orupembe-Kaokoveld.jpg|thumb|300px|Landscape north of Orupembe, Namibia]] The '''Kaokoveld Desert''' is a [[deserts and xeric shrublands|coastal desert]] of northern [[Namibia]] and southern [[Angola]].
==Setting== The Kaokoveld Desert occupies a coastal strip covering {{convert|45,700|km2|sqmi|sp=us}}, from 13° to 21°S and is bounded by the [[Atlantic Ocean]] to the west, the [[Namibian savanna woodlands]] to the east, and the [[Namib Desert]] to the south. It includes the Mossamedes Desert of southern Angola. The Kaokoveld is a harsh desert of drifting sandunes and rocky mountains. It receives most of its rainfall during the summer, which distinguishes it from the adjacent Namib Desert to the south, which receives most of its rain during the winter. The [[Kunene River]] is the only permanent watercourse but many dry riverbeds (including the [[Hoanib]], [[Hoarusib]] and [[Khumib River]]s) carry moisture through the desert and are home to animals including elephants, black rhinos, and giraffe. Other than those the area is ancient desert sand, moistened by occasional coastal fog.
==Flora== The Kaokoveld is home to ''[[Welwitschia mirabilis]]'', a plant that has no close living relatives.
==Fauna== The Kaokoveld is home to a number of endemic reptiles while large mammals including [[desert elephant]]s (''Loxodonta africana''), black rhinos (''[[Diceros bicornis]]'') and giraffes (''[[Giraffa camelopardalis]]'') visit the riverbeds. There is a great deal of birdlife including the endemic Cinderella waxbill (''[[Estrilda thomensis]]'') on the Kunene River.
==Threats and preservation== [[Skeleton Coast National Park]] runs for 500 km along the coast of Namibia and is the main protected area in the region, along with other smaller conservancies inland. Much of the area was formerly protected under Game Reserve 2, which was reduced in size to become [[Etosha National Park]] in 1967, with a subsequent increase in poaching and more recently uncontrolled off-road driving. There is an area of sand dunes in [[Iona National Park]] in Angola.
==External links== * {{NatGeo ecoregion|id=at1310|name=Kaokoveld desert}} * {{WWF ecoregion|name=Kaokoveld desert|id=at1310}} * [http://www.erongominerals.com/kaokoland.html Kaokoveld Minerals (Erongominerals.com)]

page.title: List of North American cities by population

revision.text:
For the majority of cities in [[North America]], the most recent official population census results, estimates or short-term projections date to 2015. This list compiles figures for all North American cities with a population [[city proper|within city limits]] exceeding 500,000 that year. These figures do not reflect the population of the [[urban area|urban agglomeration]] or [[metropolitan area]] which typically do not coincide with the administrative boundaries of the city. They refer to mid-2015 populations with the following exceptions: #Mexican cities, whose figures derive from the 2015 Intercensal Survey conducted by [[National Institute of Statistics and Geography|INEGI]] with a reference date of 15 March 2015;<ref name=MXdate>{{cite web |url=http://www.inegi.org.mx/est/contenidos/proyectos/encuestas/hogares/especiales/ei2015/doc/eic_2015_presentacion.pdf |title=Encuesta Intercensal 2015: Presentación de resultados |page=5 |publisher=[[INEGI]] |accessdate=2016-11-08}}</ref> #Calgary, whose 2015 municipal census had a reference date of April 1;<ref name=2015MAPL/> #Edmonton, which conducted municipal censuses in April 2014 and April 2016 but has not reported an [[intercensal estimate]] of its 2015 population. The April 2016 census result is given instead.
{{clear}}

{{Use British English|date=September 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2015}} [[File:Flag of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands.svg|thumb|right|[[Flag of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands]]]] '''List of administrative heads of Cocos (Keeling) Islands''' is article on the list of executives.
(Dates in italics indicate ''de facto'' continuation of office, irrespective of continuation of status of that office)
{| class="wikitable" ! Term ! Incumbent ! Notes |- |23 November 1955||'''[[Cocos (Keeling) Islands|Cocos (Keeling) Islands Territory]]''' of [[Australia|The Commonwealth of Australia]]|| |- |23 November 1955 to 13 November 1957||'''[[H. J. Suthern]]''', Official Representative|| |- |29 July 1972 to 16 July 1975||'''[[C. McManus]]''', Official Representative|| |- |23 July 1975 to 15 November 1977||'''[[Robert James Linford]]''', Administrator|| |- |16 November 1977 to ''25 July 1979''||'''[[Charles Ivens Buffett]]''', Administrator|| |- |25 July 1979||''Autonomy granted''|| |- |''25 July 1979'' to 31 December 1981||'''[[Charles Ivens Buffett]]''', Administrator||(contd.) |- |21 April 1982 to 22 November 1983||'''[[Eric Herbert Hanfield]]''', Administrator|| |- |14 December 1983 to ''6 April 1984''||'''[[Kenneth Chan (administrator)|Kenneth Chan]]''', Administrator|| |- |6 April 1984||''Integrated with Australia in an act of [[self-determination]]'' (see [[Cocos (Keeling) Islands status referendum, 1984|1984 status referendum]]) |- |''6 April 1984'' to 19 November 1985||'''[[Kenneth Chan (administrator)|Kenneth Chan]]''', Administrator||(contd.) |- |20 November 1985 to December 1987||'''[[Carolyn Stuart]]''', Administrator|| |- |January 1988 to 30 June 1988||'''[[W. N. Syrette]]''', acting Administrator|| |- |1 July 1988 to 7 November 1988||'''[[M. Jopling]]''', acting Administrator|| |- |8 November 1988 to 27 November 1990||'''[[Dawn Lawrie]]''', Administrator|| |- |1 December 1990 to 4 December 1992||'''[[Barry T. Cunningham]]''', Administrator|| |- |5 December 1992 to 4 December 1994||'''[[John Bell Read]]''', Administrator|| |- |4 December 1994 to 31 January 1995||'''[[Danny Ambrose Gillespie]]''', acting Administrator|| |- |1 February 1995 to 30 January 1996||'''[[Martin Mowbray]]''', Administrator|| |- |1 February 1996 to ''1 July 1996''||'''[[Jarl Andersson]]''', acting Administrator|| |- |1 July 1996||Part of '''[[Australian Indian Ocean Territories]]'''|| |- |''1 July 1996'' to 12 April 1997||'''[[Jarl Andersson]]''', acting Administrator||(contd.) |- |12 April 1997 to 30 September 1997||'''[[Maureen Ellis]]''', acting Administrator|| |- |1 October 1997 to 30 October 1998||'''[[Ronald Harvey (administrator)|Ronald George Harvey]]''', acting Administrator|| |- |1 November 1998 to present||'''the [[List of administrative heads of Christmas Island|administrators]] of [[Christmas Island]]'''|| |- |}
''Note:'' The Administrator of [[Cocos (Keeling) Islands]] is also Administrator of [[Australian Indian Ocean Territories]] since 1 July 1996, and Administrator of the [[Christmas Island]] since 1 November 1998.
